title: How to Play Bughouse Chess

steps.headline: Divide the players into two teams.
steps.description: Try to divide the stronger players evenly.

steps.headline: Sit each team across the table from the other.
steps.description: Have the stronger players on each team sit across from each other, and the weaker players face each other as well.

steps.headline: Place a chessboard between each opposing pair of players.
steps.description: Remember that the bottom right square should be white, like in a normal chess game.

steps.headline: Set up the boards as in normal chess.
steps.description: You and the teammate next to you play different colors: if you're playing as black, he or she will be white, and vice versa.

steps.headline: Start your clocks.
steps.description: Place the clocks on the outsides so that all players can see them. The players with black pieces typically start their clocks simultaneously. A move is completed only when the clock is pressed. This step is optional, see the Tips below.

steps.headline: Begin play as if it were a normal game.
steps.description: However, when you take an opponent's piece, you hand it to your teammate.

steps.headline: Place the pieces you receive from your teammate in reserve, or use your turn to put it on the board.
steps.description: You can place a piece anywhere on the board, unless it would put your opponent in check. Also, pawns cannot be placed on the first or last row. You don't have to place a piece immediately after you receive it; you can place it on any turn, but it uses that turn.

steps.headline: Checkmate on any board ends the game.
steps.description: The player that checkmates his or her opponent wins the game for his or her team.

text: Divide the players into two teams. Try to divide the stronger players evenly. Sit each team across the table from the other. Have the stronger players on each team sit across from each other, and the weaker players face each other as well. Place a chessboard between each opposing pair of players. Remember that the bottom right square should be white, like in a normal chess game. Set up the boards as in normal chess. You and the teammate next to you play different colors: if you're playing as black, he or she will be white, and vice versa. Start your clocks. Place the clocks on the outsides so that all players can see them. The players with black pieces typically start their clocks simultaneously. A move is completed only when the clock is pressed. This step is optional, see the Tips below. Begin play as if it were a normal game. However, when you take an opponent's piece, you hand it to your teammate. Place the pieces you receive from your teammate in reserve, or use your turn to put it on the board. You can place a piece anywhere on the board, unless it would put your opponent in check. Also, pawns cannot be placed on the first or last row. You don't have to place a piece immediately after you receive it; you can place it on any turn, but it uses that turn. Checkmate on any board ends the game. The player that checkmates his or her opponent wins the game for his or her team.
